GJsRGdnvfGsG3w0becDD2w.review_text: Cool space, great beer selection, friendly knowledgeable staff and delicious French fries. I like the style of the beer menu with the beers grouped by the temperature they are served at and I appreciated that the staff  are well educated about each beer on the list and can provide good guidance. Did I mention the French fries?

C3Hpsx_eDfeSmxEc1HBzpA.review_text: MIkkeller Bar is an awesome joint with a huge beer selection. It doesn't take long to figure out you come for the brews and the food.   Their food menu is small and largely consists of wheat based items and sausage. I didn't end up eating here but stopped by for a couple of drinks. As far as booze goes, you have 42 choices of beer and a few wine varieties to choose from. I actually tried their cab...don't make fun...I wasn't feeling the beer. It wasn't very good but that's my mistake!  You don't come to a place known for their beer and order wine. Shame on me.   If you're a fan of craft beer than you'll love it here.

FgGiQc9zpM_va5JZMvJtMQ.review_text: Right out of left field comes a beautiful space/bar with a beautiful array of beers. I have only been here once so this review probably warrants another visit for more detail. However, after managing to pick a few (delicious) specialty beers from their extensive (draft) menu, I think it may warrant many more visits anyway.   I had a few, so I'll admit my memory doesn't completely serve, but I had a particularly delicious Black IPA called Space Invader; I highly recommend. I also tried one of their wild yeast beers, and it was a flowery explosion of how beer should taste.   HIGHLY friendly bar tenders, surprisingly attentive service for the large crowd, yet plenty of space to accommodate it. Another first-time note that always informs the response is the bathroom situation. After drinking a few beers, (depending upon your bladder capacity), your highest hope is a lineless bathroom. Especially as a human of the lady-persuasion, this hope cannot be more desired. Despite the thick crowd, the bathroom was BARREN. Hells yes. There are multiple stalls and multiple sinks, and cleanliness was not left wanting.   Upon my next visit I'll be sure to check out the food situation. My thinking is that any place with excellent beer that also offers food must also have excellent food.

V9kaoXCiVblzH-x17uVuaw.review_text: The beers on tap will blow your mind. Not the usual Tap House list of brews either. Fantastic beers you've never heard of and the servers will helpfully guide you through the latest offerings.   The food was more or less solid gastro pub fare, not amazing but not poor. Started with the lil smokies which were a great opening salvo to lube the belly for the beer to come.  Definitely a share size portion. Had the Ruben and was definitely not let down. Would definitely go back to try a few of the other menu offerings.    Service was solid and the server was attentive, personal, and never felt rushed despite a full house.

Z1RH6tFaNRsJUJ5gaV0j_w.review_text: Really good crowd and nice (but limited) menu. Great selection of beers and helpful bartenders. Only complaint is that the neighborhood is kind of sketchy. Definitely recommend for a group or someone flying solo (plenty of bar seats).

txOz8PIJbMlEdl5CLnpsXA.review_text: We're actually here right now... The hostess was friendly... The waiter who finally took our drink order was friendly...  But what horrid bartenders... We waited for 20 minutes before the waiter acknowledged us... We moved two spots trying to get their attention...  The beers are great but first time impression tells me the bartenders needs more practice serving a small crowd... At least smile while u rudely blow the customers off...

5SWhTOrEU_-W-2jB6rXUGA.review_text: This is a great SF spot in a central location. I met friends for a late drink, so we didn't try any food. It was quiet on a week night, making it the perfect location to catch up. Though I don't imbibe alcohol, I enjoyed a Fentiman's Ginger Beer.

phoMcYUbBJeAKUD0GE76GA.review_text: Loved the beer selection. That's what you came here for, right? I'll definitely be returning to try them all. If I start raving about the beer here, I won't be able to stop, so let's just say they have a veritable bible of a beer menu. Required reading, fa sho.  But don't think that beer is the only reason to visit Mikkeller. They have a solid food menu that pairs nicely with beer, too. Food came in big portions, relatively quickly, and the kitchen was flexible with requested modifications. Loved the prison-style metal trays. The bratwurst was crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside, and thick. They give you a HEAP of fries, which make for good beer-munchies food. Another party next to us had the sausage platter, which looked phenomenal. I was pretty envious. The banh mi sandwich was surprisingly traditional with the style of bread and toppings, with the exception of the char-siu-style tofu. The tofu was bit on the sweet side, a bit crispily charred, and surprisingly meaty tasting.  The bartenders are friendly. The décor is nothing adventurous, but it's still cozy and charming, with dim orangey lights, lots of wooden furniture, metal piping, and paintings that make me think of the Earl of Lemongrab from Adventure Time. The high roof makes it feel quite open.  Will have to return for the sour room downstairs and sausage platter.

mE-hdFF4RgCxspZU72GAsw.review_text: Excellent new life in the deep Tenderloin. The force behind Mikkeller fought the tide and their risk was rewarded with a full house of thirsty beer lovers in one of the worst hoods of SF (which isn't saying much these days.) Been a few times now. Most recently the menu was a tad unbalanced on the hoppy and pumpkiny side. 5 IPAs, 3 PA, 1 APA, and 3 pumpkin or fruit beers.  What about some old fashioned English bitter? Or something a tad more malty? I mean I've been quaffing hoppy brews since '92, and how the tide on buttery Chardonnays suddenly changed, I'm predicting a crash in hops soon as well. I'll welcome that. In the meantime, Mikkeller, please offer one session beer. Please.  As for the food, the sausages were outstanding btw, even a tad better than the famous Rosamunde on lower Haight I dare say. The PEI mussels left much to desire though, I would steer clear of those scrawny guys for the time being. Hope to return soon.

D-rKFBb1s4_4vpDA9Wjiog.review_text: This place is super crowded, but the food and beers here are great.  The sausage platter is fantastic, and they have great fries.

PECXedG2F9cOUN_9Otru6Q.review_text: Great selection of beers and by great selection I mean a whole lot of stuff I've never heard of.  It's nice to go in to a place like that and not see the standard selection. The service was excellent.   We didn't eat anything but the food looked very good.

JeS7ciQNAY6seqFVrhsIuw.review_text: Amazing beer selection.  I'm not THAT into beer but beer geeks are sure to find something interesting to try.    as for the salty accompaniments that made a good beer even better ...  O. M. G. the fries!  The fries!!!!!

m5qPtj0n1Ncenxjm76qKOA.review_text: I can't really vouch for the food or beverage selection. They don't allow infants into the place even for lunch. It is therefor a bar, not a gastropub. The biggest problem, though, was the rudeness with which the message was delivered. The least he could do was act like he would want our business another time or apologize for the inconvenience. I understand if you can't bend certain rules that are clearly ridiculous in particular situations, but there was no one else in the place other than the friends I was there to meet so at least take the time to be polite.

2MvxF5Ca3kSaJ_LDO_FfBQ.review_text: Because my husband is really into beer, we tend to come here for the special events and at times when it isn't crowded. The one time we came here when it was packed our experience wasn't as good, since the main bar is strangely shaped, which means that sometimes it takes the staff a while to get over to you.  That said, this place is really great over all. Especially when it's somewhat empty or for special events in the downstairs room. The beer selection, both on tap and in bottles is pretty stellar, and their food is good!  But the best-kept secret here is the french fries. These may just be the best fries in the city. They rival the best fries I've ever had with their crispy outer layer and chewy inside. Nicely salted and seasoned with just the right amount of grease. Perfect texture and flavor and perfect beer-drinking-food.

YLfyhDaQBs_2bfJBNLBt_w.review_text: Overrated in my opinion. I don't see what all the hype is about.   - The beer selection isn't that impressive compared to other gastropubs in SF or the East Bay.  - Weak pours and they use the wrong type of glassware -- IPA in a chalice?? - Overpriced. - It's infested with socially inept tech nerds glued to their phones. For the record, I work in software and I don't want to be around nerds when I'm outside the office (~8hrs/day is enough). - Awful location. - GOD DAMN IT'S LOUD IN THERE!!!!!!  Glad I tried it, but I'll stick to my normal spots.

xYB4vwPiFhxMHS0ctdpTig.review_text: Love the beer selection and food.Go downstairs in the evening for private parties.

ILz8ApVEgTqbv5LnC6PyuA.review_text: Heaven. Seriously, probably the best bar in the city, let alone the country. Granted I've been drinking Mikkeller for many years now so I'm pretty biased, but the selection can't be beat. The food is VERY good as well. I've had many of the items on the menu and none disappointed. And now they are open for lunch too?!

76XALoo0pOgAeGvDRzc21w.review_text: Nice beer selection of course! Wasn't crazy about the Bratwurst, the inside was not fully cooked! My friend's Reuben was very greasy, but good.  Unless I'm in the area, I would not go out of my way to come here.

0H2ggT37lK8hsbH8aGR1Ug.review_text: 8/30/14: This was the middlelish stop of our epic beer tour which started at Lagunitas and would go on to include Russian River, Rogue, Cellarmaker, here, Monk's Kettle, and finally Speakeasy, all over 2 days!  I was looking forward to coming here cause they make some of the yummiest beers I've bought.  Was a great bonus to also be a nice restaurant, garbed in the usual trendy woods and metal.  1. Spontangooseberry: Sorry, I didn't take notes on this sour beer, but I do remember it being delicious and really hit the spot.  2. P. E. I. Mussels $12:  For $12, this was a TON of mussels.  When they say a pound, they really mean it.  I don't think I've ever had such a large order of mussels anywhere!--quite a surprise for a fancier place.  Unfortunately, the mussels themselves kinda sucked.  They were very shrunken in their shells which probably meant that they were overcooked.  This was unfortunate as the sauce was sublime.  If they had cooked the mussels large and juicy I would say this bowl would have been one of the best bowls of mussel to have ever been put in front of my face.  But can't give 9 or 10 if the basic ingredient wasn't cooked well right?  Very sadly, with MUCH potential, 6/10.  Well, I'm willing to believe that my mussels were just a fluke.  The stuff my friends ordered looked beautiful, and well, we all know their beer is world class.  4/5.  #pub #bar #beer #brewery

QTWeTvQ5HLDRRhTNiLiojw.review_text: So, last night was New Years Eve and I found myself tossing my cookies at 3:00 a.m. This would seem likely a result of NYE revelry, but in fact, no, it was an unfortunate consequence of my dinner at Mikkeller Bar. At the time, I had mostly enjoyed my dinner. We started with an order of fries and lil' smokies, as well as a couple of beers. Yum! We then shared the kale caesar salad with anchovies (pretty good) and an order of their ribs. The moment I put the rib to my mouth I noticed the overwhelming smoky odor. Not unusual for such an odor to be present, but the smell was so strong it took my breath away. I went through with eating it; however, it was chewy and tasteless (minus the smoky flavor). Fast forward to 3:00 a.m. and I am praying at the porcelain altar revisiting that same smoky taste. Remarkably, it was even stronger the second time around! Two stars because most of the food tasted good (going down), the atmosphere is cool, and the service was attentive.

K-Gc9Ky7aRkiOSUQ3EEaLA.review_text: FAIL.  I am deathly allergic to nuts, so I always ask about nuts when I order. I came here for a work lunch and the waiter swore that the mortadella sausage had no nuts, even though all mortadella I've ever seen contains pistachios.   UPDATE: thanks to the management for confirming the mortadella indeed is nut free and for a quick reply to my review.    However, the bread is all from Acme, which are all labeled as possibly containing nuts. The waiter said he was sure there were no nuts in the bread. Had I not known better, I might have had a really bad day at the hospital.  It would be good if the waitstaff just admitted they were not sure or made more effort to verify.   Beyond that the beer is disappointing.  The cask conditioned IPA looked like a cup of cold piss and underwhelmed by any measure.    Fries were fair.  Bathroom smelled like stale urine at noon on a Friday.    p.s. FAIL.

A5zEX9F29FlFmVQA9xbzhQ.review_text: Terrible. Would have loved to check the place out but the front of house staff member denied my boyfriend and I entry because as non-American tourists (we're from Australia) we apparently needed to show our passports and not our drivers licences. This is the only place we've encountered in San Francisco and the USA to have such a ridiculous requirement.   Based on a brief google sesh, it appears that CA law requires ID checks to ensure a person has a bona fide form of identification. Last I checked, non-US drivers licences are pretty damn bona fide (so long as they are legit and valid!) US domestic airlines accept our licences at the security gates!  Train your staff, or stop hiring d-bags to work your front door. Or if the whole passport requirement is unique to your venue, tourists beware, this joint won't be worth it unless you intend to wonder the streets with your passport.   Luckily after trotting out of the joint annoyed and amazed, we wondered over to the Press Club a few streets away. The Press Club is a swanky wine bar that also serves a great selection of craft beer. We had a lovely time splashing our tourist dollars there instead.   PS if I could give this place 0 stars I would, but Yelp's mobile app doesn't let me (hint to Yelp: let us post 0 star ratings!)

daYV5IBz88PVLDifv32Epg.review_text: Went here on a Saturday night. I was very impressed by the beer selection, which featured a surprising number of beers that I've never tried. The ambiance was quite nice, and our server was very friendly. I got the reuben, which was a little on the small side but tasted great. I definitely plan to come back!

dsBY5eS8qMdzLcc2EGWRig.review_text: Mikkeller is a cool hang out spot that is right by my work. It's convenient because I can just walk here after work. Although they don't have a large menu for food, everything that I've had was pretty good. They have a huge selection of beer which I believe they brew themselves. If you love beer, this is the place for you! The decor is very modern and it looks very new and clean inside. The only problem I have with this place is that it is hard to find seating most of the time. Unless you are with a large group, the staff suggest that you find your own seating which is first come, first serve. Overall, this is a pretty decent place. I suggest checking it out!

_wXAIReuoJ0lYZY-m3AehQ.review_text: Great beer, better atmosphere, best bartenders

Kr9sA9gKISX5i8WN4_nXcQ.review_text: This is as close to heaven as you'll get if you like beer and awesome food...the location is not great, but if you know where you're going and find yourself at mikkeller...you will not be disappointed.  The staff is friendly and very knowledgeable about their beers, the place is always hopping and overall is a great place to bring a group, kick back and enjoy everything they offer.

8fSaLfemE1G403PMJzfATw.review_text: Ahh Mikkeller Bar you are so worth it.  To make myself sound pretentious: I went to the original Mikkeller in Copenhagen over the summer and the bartenders there were excited to say that Mikkeller Bar was going to be opening in SF, they were even wearing the shirts. They then asked me if the Tenderloin was a nice neighborhood. I explained the current state of affairs and they explained that the original Mikkeller had a similar location.  But alas, it is totally worth going to Mikkeller even if you are a bit concerned about the location. I have not been hassled in the surrounding areas at any of the times I have gone, ranging from a 3 o'clock late lunch to a 10:30PM night out.  The bar upstairs fills up pretty quickly, but you can put your name in with the hostess and wait for a table if you desire. There are TONS of fantastic beers on tap, all served at specific temperatures thanks to their nifty tap system. They focus primarily on the Scandinavian beers but have a lot of US and other countries' craft offerings as well.  The secret gem is the sour room downstairs. They have two special taps only available in that room. The sour beers will require some taste retraining for some, but they are a great change of pace from the current IPA, Hop Heavy offerings of most craft establishments.  But that's just the beginning, Mikkeller's food is actually awesome too! Bacon wrapped cocktail hotdogs (weiners typed just sounds so creepy) deep fried, smoked sausages, pastrami sandwiches all offerings that pair perfectly with the assortment of beer.  I have taken tons of friends here and even took my mom to the sour room. No one has been disappointed. I highly recommend checking it out!

mzL0zHFGyd9866OUljq49g.review_text: Having been to the Mikkeller bar in Copenhagen, I already knew that I was going to enjoy this place.  We didn't stay for long, just a couple of beers but this location is larger than the other one I went to and stocked with plenty of delicious hard to find beers.  The bar is quite large and the servers were very nice.  We opted for seats around the back side of the bar so we could appropriately people watch.  The layout is very accessible and easy to navigate.  As I said, we only drank but we had a good time doing that.  I would definitely come back here the next time I'm in town.

NMGpx_BYBwx9Z7SyI3Wd4A.review_text: I don't like beer and I don't like gastropubs, and this place still managed to impress me! Experience on a Wednesday night:  --Friendly and knowledgeable service.  --According to the beer people in my group, a great selection.  --I had a glass of wine and even--ack--a beer. Who knew that REAL Lambic isn't sweet? Dry and sour. Loved it.  --Great decor. Modern but comfy. Spacious/cavernous feeling unlike yucky/stinky dive bars.  --Well-thought-out menu that includes vegetarians.  --No TVs. THANK YOU!  Good job, ya'll!

nfzdme1_TjrCHkQu3wV3lA.review_text: An excellent beer selection, good eats and a staff of hometown expats made me feel right at home in the middle of The City.  First off, the tap list is highly respectable, full of both norcal locals and a surprising  few that were familiar to this SD native.   I hemmed and hawed over appetizer or salad with my lunch, and on recommendation I went with my now-predictable La quercia prosciutto which came with figs, pears, balsamic, and while those other elements were all quite good, the burrata elevated the already formidable game of the norcal variety to new heights: this was deeply rich yet light in texture as a mascarpone or ricotta; definitely a Wow item.   My main, a garlic link, was guaranteed to be a letdown after that; like the prosciutto and figs it was merely quite good. Lean, pleasantly garlicky, and a large portion.  Also, be aware that the one side-of-fries would have been enough for three hungry people, so order additional starches at your peril.  I came in at the height of the lunch hour and it was not at all crowded; a nice change from the jam-packed business-lunch eateries nearby.

-1NPkYRiwkqNqImT9pQFag.review_text: I'm not beer guy...this place made me real happy. The blood is great and French fries are YUMMY! Gets packed fast so grab a spot quick.

2AgNI9hlQfScB_SB3RNTIQ.review_text: I frequent other Mikkeller interests like Beefcafe Ol and Perdition. The beer is good.  My gripe with this place is with the management in SF, not the staff.  Maybe its because this is a high volume establishment on the edge of the tenderloin?  Maybe its because the general manager was having a bad night?  Accidents happen and so do beer spills.  While handing my friends their beers, I accidentally spilled my own.  After helping clean it up, I noticed no one was around behind the bar.  Usually one would expect a replacement beer poured without reservation.  Instead, I received attitude from the general manager and a flat out refusal for a replacement beer with logic along the lines of "Why should I absorb that? That will cost us another beer."  Well, I'm thinking - it will cost you a lot more than that: my business, my friends business, my recommendation, and possibly anyone reading this review too.  If that's the type of attitude that management wants to teach their employees, I have other places I can go.  Forget this place and the manager's bad attitude.

K91tc8YmQGbGcIJFVlBGvQ.review_text: GF and I had our car smashed and luggage stolen *right* outside the bar.  Bouncer said this was not an issue but clearly it is!  Seems as if another person did as well based on the other reviews.  Bar itself is beautiful.  Was not happy with staff however.  Their descriptions of beers was way off and they kept pushing beers we did not enjoy.  OTOH some amazing beers were had.  TORST in NYC is far far better (and safer).  I hope they outgrow their growing pains and get that neighborhood cleaned up.  Until then, take mass transit, go in groups or avoid altogether.

UfwU6p1_wvqm4H1uSX2-rw.review_text: Popped in around 7ish with my wife and friend.  The joint had a good vibe.  The beer menu lists many beers and the temperature they are served at, which I thought was pretty neat.  Different beers are served at different temperatures for optimal taste.  The food was decent as well.  You go here for the beers and order some food so you don't stumble out when the night is over.

drI9J9xeWephVGlfMC487w.review_text: I wanted to fall in love with Mikkeller Bar, I really did. when I checked out their beer list on line, it made my mouth water. The space itself is gorgeous. And,  I mean, how can you NOT love a place that lists their brews by what temperature its served. How very European! I didn't ned up ordering what I thought. I had visions of a frosty Mikkeller Orange Yuzu Glad I Said Porter (Grand Marnier). But having downed several whiskey/rye cocktails earlier in the evening, I decided to try the Jolly Pumpkin Bière De Mars. It has a sour bite that makes it go great with sausage. Since sausage was on my brain, that part of my plan worked our perfectly. I really loved the fries (uber crisp) and my bratwurst (juicy!). But my dining pleasure was thrown completely off track by my dessert. The taste was good, but the texture was just off. I was tired that night, so it may just be me being cranky, but I'm pretty sure it was only listed It as a chocolate creme brulee. When I went on line later, the menu said cookies and creme (although the description sounds like the cookies will be on the side). Cookie crumbs folded into the creme might explain the grainy texture I encountered. Might. I couldn't eat more than a couple of bites, and believe me, I do NOT skip dessert. Bad dessert roughly translate to 1.5 stars missing. One more star is gone because of a reserved table. Again, I was tired, so maybe I am just being cranky. I have no problem with reserved tables. I've reserved a few in my time for sure. I just find it suspect that a group of the staff took over the one in question. For some reason that annoys me to no end. My friend and I found a seat elsewhere, and truth be told, it was too big a spot for us, but I can't help but think it might have been better off used for paying customers. And yes, it colud have been a special occasion, or it could have been a work perk, or any number of things that make that perfectly legit. I just happened to be tire and a bit cranky.If you add that up, this is really more of a 2.5 rating. And, depending on if I had been at a less tired/cranky moment, it might even be more if a 3.5. that said, please fix the dessert if you haven't already. You can't mess with dessert. I'm not sauting through the Tenderloin again for bad chocolate.

w-pGm1MfyHRvbL1x5NxiMA.review_text: Being a craft fan in the South Bay, I've known of Mikkeller for awhile. It's just a matter of having the stars align where I can make it up to SF with proper/safe transport and being in the right general vicinity.  Now I've been to the bar twice and I think it's a great experience. For those of you who don't know, the twin brothers who own Mikkeller and Evil Twin have their own bars as well. During my vacation back to my hometown of Brooklyn, I visited Torst. Which was cool, but Mikkeller IMO is a better space, more easier to get to and I preferred it over the two. Pretty funny for me because I like beers of Evil Twin better!  + Great food. I thought this was top notch. + Pretty awesome beer menu. Unique guest taps, lots of representation and served at right temp. + Environment is optimal IMO. Large bar area, spacious and a variety of different types of seating. + I thought pricing was apt. Neither insanely high or low.  This is probably the best proper modern bar I've visited in SF. Yes, we have some classic craft bars but let's be honest -- they would redesign if they could to be more practical.

kZe2CUs-9OeIViFa6QC0wA.review_text: Awesome food and beer list. They have a good selection of draft and bottled beers, many of which I had never heard of so that was really exciting to try new beers. We ordered the half smoked sausage sandwich with fries, and the mussels. The service was friendly and the interior is open and modern.

cLDb8TcSUnbdyR81f0eRcA.review_text: This place is AWESOME. I needed a casual spot to meet up with a coworker who was in from out of town, and this was perfect. I had the spicy italian sausage, and it was seriously so flavorful and delicious. The salad was a great accompaniment, and was perfectly (and mildly) dressed. Finished up with their bread pudding - and I'm happy to report that it didn't have raisins in it. I'm not usually a fan of dried cherries but they really worked here. Bonus: I needed to charge my phone, so the bartender offered me several different types of chargers and set us up near an outlet. They clearly know their audience well.

S741Gd3CAQKJnpe1j7QKFQ.review_text: This gastro pub is fairly popular, especially on a Friday night around 7 pm. And for good reason. The bartenders are extremely accommodating especially our bartender, Josh. He was very patient with us and other customers. We even wrote him a thank you note on our receipt. Josh, if you're reading this, the Chua sisters are incredibly grateful that you were our bartender.   As for the food, it was really good. We ordered the salted cod fish cake, mussels dish, and the kale Caesar salad. The broth that came with the mussels was smokey and well seasoned. I could drink that broth forever.   Thanks for making our visit to San Francisco special!

I90lkun-9pei6UXjJnP_FQ.review_text: Douchey beer tourists. Good beer selection,  but it's infested with beer tourists from all over that get in the way of good drinking.

hp4EfXvHbwFLyczlFz9WlQ.review_text: People have addressed almost every aspect of this place, so I just want to briefly highlight a few stand-out points.  What a fabulous way to spend a late Sunday afternoon (I've gone twice now on a Sunday around 5 p.m.) - totally relaxing, not noisy at all at that time, and the staff is sooo attentive and helpful.  I especially appreciated the recs (and samples) they gave off menu when I told them the kind of beer I had in mind.  (Yesterday I had an off-menu Tahoe Mountain sour with apricot that knocked my socks off, since the Tenderloin Spontanle I'd had the week before was no longer listed.)  Anyway, this is becoming my happy late Sunday place, and I hope others give it a shot, too.

tXB9AU_kExPs5LClEREzLg.review_text: I really did like this bar, but today I was here and asked for a recommended beer. They brought me out the Tenderloin IPA. It tasted flat to me and I simply did not enjoy it. I only took one sip and did not drink the whole beer. I went to the bar and politely asked for a different beer. The man helping me just looked at me and was rude about not switching out the beer. That's the first time I've ever been to a beer house and they did not kindly switch out a beer that tasted bad to me. Hopefully it was a one-time thing.   Note to the bartender, if a customer doesn't enjoy a beer that was recommended to them, help them find one they will enjoy!

ITa3vh5ERI90G_WP4SmGUQ.review_text: Beer nerds, rejoice.   Everyone else, try to stay out of the way as the beer nerds coat the 42 spotless taps, extensive and amazing bottle list, and spotless wooden tables with their drool.* This Danish brewery has achieved legendary status amongst those that worship hops, and this, their first American venture, is offering up some of the unique and intesne flavors they are known for.  Orange Yuzu Glad I Said Porter? Yes.  Big Worster Barrel Aged Barley Wine? I think so.  Arh Hvad?! Sauternes Saison? Of course.  Tenderloin Spontanale Lambic? Why not.   And that's just a few of the brews available from Mikkeller, not even including the obscure and wonderful offerings from other breweries. Throw in a tasty-sounding menu of small plates (unfortunately I have yet to try them), and you never have to leave.   And by never, I actually mean you can stay until midnight, which is apparently when they close up shop because they've decided they don't want all the money in my pocket. ____________  *And other bodily fluids that shall remain nameless.

X9Z5sdrX_LwYX1jlLcY3Mw.review_text: We found this place on a tip from our Uber driver.  It's a funky Belgian gastropub with seriously good small plates and beer on tap!  Our group of three split the sausage platter which was excellent. It came with a few slices of toasted rye bread, but we also ordered a basket of fries to go with it.  The beer tap system is specially engineered to serve each beer at a specific temperature according to the beer style. It was very cool, and you could taste the difference!  Only cons are that it's a little pricey, and the wall art is weird. Also, I thought there were a few too many fruit/high-gravity/"spontaneous" beers on tap.

7y7zD8-ktgj2faQ3ZLHnnQ.review_text: The Mikkeller Bar has a nice selection of craft beer available, and they know how to properly deliver it to you. Each beer comes in the right glassware, is served at the right temperature, and is poured properly. Bartenders are also very knowledgeable about the beer on the menu. Mikkeller also has good food options available here. There are a couple downsides: 1) No TVs inside, so if you're hoping to catch sports you'll want to go elsewhere. 2) Service wasn't the best - had to go up to the bar to get drinks because a server never came by to take an order.

zEik36GV9GlRoSxEa_F6Yw.review_text: We waited in line for almost two hours during the soft opening.  I was starting to get a little antsy but once we got in, it was all worth it.  The interior is nice and spacious and I really liked the relatively simple decor.  I heard that they shipped the lighting fixtures in straight from Denmark!  The servers were surprisingly competent and on it.....not that I expected anything less, but the place had literally been (unofficially) open for 2 hours!    The beer:  Oh man, the beer.  It was all amazing.  I decided to go with all Mikkellers since they are hard to find on tap generally.  Had the chipotle stout, the milk stout and the cream ale.  I would order all of them again.  The milk stout was probably my favorite.  It was like candy.  The chipotle stout also had that nice punch of heat at the end.  And the cream ale was so smooth.  It was light and refreshing but still had body.  The food:    we ordered fries.  The first batch we had to send back because they werent cooked enough, but the second batch was perfect.  the little smokies were little hot dogs wrapped in bacon.  not much can go wrong there.  the fish and potato cakes - delicious.  Not to fishy.  the chicken wings -- we had the soy chicken wings and the korean chicken wings.  both were good, but the soy wings were crispier and had me wanting more.  The korean chicken wings could have been a little bit crispier, and although i liked the flavor better on these, I did not necessarily want more of them.  Bratwurst - Really good!  I don't necessarily go for Brats, but I would order another one of those any day.  All in all, it was amazing how great it was considering that they weren't even officially opened yet.  I will probably hold off on going back until after they officially open and let some of the buzz die down, but don't let that stop you from going!  You will NOT be disappointed!

WW02Suiiv9dGHVqWhCl5kQ.review_text: This place has a great selection of beers but it can get pretty pricey depending what you get. Also got their sausage wrapped in bacon dish and I found it to be quite salty, but I didn't really care cause its bacon and sausage which are both salty by themselves.   The place was really crowded and loud when I went. The servers are were also quite nice and polite. I will definitely come here again to try some of the other beers.

uiSnSHkc4RwU5fTl7Daj_A.review_text: Great bar! Check out the "sour room" downstairs. It's a replica of the original taproom in Copenhagen. As a sour beer lover, this was such a cool room. They have all the sours that are sold upstairs, as well as sours you can't buy upstairs.  The bartenders were extremely helpful and knowledgable. My mom doesn't really like beer - one of the bartenders talked to her for 10 minutes and gave her many samples to help her find a beer she would like.   They have 40 beers on tap and an extensive bottle list.   I will definitely be going back

t8PHQKLAtNXh5w8MQB9Fpw.review_text: Came here for a quick bite and knew nothing about what I was supposed to do. It was pretty crowded on a Monday night (6pmish) and it's free seating. My friend and I finally found some seats. It took a while for the waitress to notice us, but when she finally got to us she was very nice. I told her I knew nothing about beer as it was my first time in a bar like this and she suggested the least alcoholic beers on the menu... good choice. They have a HUGE selection of draft beers.  We ended up ordering: - milk stout: a strong dark beer  - longfin: basically the best tasting lite beer ever - saucisson a l'ail: not bad, the onions made it delicious - smoked sausage: bomb dot com, super flavorful - fries: soooo crispy and delicious with the malt vinegar ketchup  Since the waitress knew that I had a very limited knowledge of beer, she brought over 2 samples, something that had hints of raspberries and something with santa in the name. That was very thoughtful of her.  Overall I had a nice experience, however I wish it was a little more organized in the seating.

JnGtgOPpkjyWOvWM0SYEXg.review_text: union square gastropub bordering the sketch of tenderloin...busy friday evening and tables/bars full...sent in early scouts to take over tables...finding the group and taking a seat....order of the "super stout" $8...not very "super" in size...cute little dainty glass of stout...full sweet dense flavors and highly potent...beers and wine flowing....bacon wrapped goods fine....pickled vegetables tasty...some lamb dish and other things unknown, but tasty...$45 sausage platter quite the sausage feast...toasty greasy crunchy bread slices quite good, but can't be healthy...some white sausage, brown sausage and darker sausage...feeling a bit gross, but all worth a bite...the food is quite heavy....the drinks are rich...the selection is all new and unknown...have to experience to find out likes and dislikes...atmosphere is crowded, but fun...the servers are on top of everything....very efficient...the drinks can get expensive for a binge, so moderate tasting is recommended...

Le_ixhoaqJAxBvvvDhI1lQ.review_text: Great spot for craft beer.   Interesting, modern space with a spacious bar. Fantastic selection of mostly American craft beers, with two on cask (yay!).  Refreshing to find an American bar that realizes not all beer should be served ice cold, and not every beer has to be a hop-bomb to be good. They actually serve their beers at different temperatures, appropriate to the style of beer.  Visited late on a Sunday evening, after the kitchen was closed, so we were unable to sample the food, but the menu looked small, but with some interesting selections.   Will be back again...

hbkzlNSNMcXEL-h3jzS2SQ.review_text: If you are a good beer fan and find yourself in the Union Square, you must come here! They have one of the best selections in the city and its a fun atmosphere. The food is good, but nothing to really ride home about. The area is Union Square, but more Tenderloin than anything (so it can be a little interesting). Definitely come give this place a try tho!

e4db8XgxP3i-7eBNtmDYkA.review_text: I was pretty excited about this bar, as my friends and I are fans of Mikkeller.  The interior of the bar is very clean and modern with an design that encourages conversation.  All the tables and the bar are of level height and there are not TVs to distract you from enjoying your meal, your beer or your company.   Some friends and I ordered several beers all of which were served in 8-10 ounce pours or 25 -30 CL (Centiliters ).  The prices are a little high for the amount of beer poured, but you are downtown SF.  We also ordered some food, the Korean fried chicken wings and the Smoked pastrami ruben.  The wings were okay, I dont' think i'd get them again, but the Ruben was amazing.  The smoked hand cut pastrami in the ruben was seriously delicious and you can totally split this sandwich with a friend, it's pretty heavy.   The location is in the heart of the TL, and i'll say I've walked through the TL plenty of times at night and it wasn't that bad.  The day we went to Mikkellers we walked through the TL around 4pm and the streets were packed with freaks.  Honestly the journey through the streets of the TL was a bit crazy this time.  Maybe i'll come back sometime in the evening.

wklRHMU2dsZeFKIRfJtrcA.review_text: I like Sierra Nevada so the bartender recommended a pale ale similar to that. It was pretty damn good! I got the beer and a braut deal afterwards but I didn't really like the pilsner it came with. The braut was huge though and super good. I got it with a salad but the dressing had a metallic taste to it :( oh well. The bartender was really friendly as was the man who I assumed to be the manager or owner. I'll be back next time I'm in the area to try more brauts and brews!  ALSO, my friend lost her phone there the night before and they had it waiting when we went there to check. I really appreciate businesses who keep lost items safe because not a lot do. :)

VdKR3WR7mMfqbhs_nuoZHw.review_text: To start this off I want to point out that I'm not a "beer guy" in any real way. Alone, I tend not to drink beer, and with friends I generally have what they are having. This is a serious beer drinkers bar in that they have a wide variety of craft beers served at specific temperatures from some back to the future time machine tap. I arrived here and looked at the beer menu, and instantly felt like an amateur. I hadn't heard of ANY of the beers on the menu. The bartender recognized my look, patiently asked about what beers I do like, and proceeded to describe different beers he thought I might like. The beers I chose, with the help of the bartender, and later a waiter, were all really delicious. I'm no connoisseur, but I know what tastes good.  Another thing I liked was the honesty of the servers. They wouldn't flat out tell you a beerwasn't good, but sometimes they helped guide me away from beers that I might not like as much.  It is a bit pricey, and the beers came in strange different sizes, making it hard to figure out how much you have had, and it did attract a yuppie crowd- but that sort of stuff is pretty par for the course in places like these. Not a watering hole for every Friday night, but a great date spot, it's definitely worth checking out

Q06xYs_C2X5fuh0AOV-I2A.review_text: Among the best, if not the best, beer you can get in San Francisco.  Mikkeller's first-ever North American location is worthy of the name: delicious beer, a great atmosphere and interior, and great food to boot.  No, it's not cheap, but for the quality on offer I'm very happy with the prices.  Mikkeller's own on the list include a few made just for the neighborhood.

shAWQnpTdaB0PD7iYzyMaQ.review_text: Order the Orange Yuzu Glad. Say it as drunk as possible when you order it.

D2epirooWNjvwTI6MFhNGw.review_text: Amazing beers. Beautiful space. Totally NOT pretentious, excellent service.  Mikkeller Tenderbrown Ale was quite delicious.  Also split a plate of pickled veggies (mushrooms, green beans, carrots, cauliflower, green tomatoes) to nosh on before dinner. YUM!  Restrooms downstairs, women to the left men to the right.  Kudos to Chuck Stilphen ,  Mikkel Borg Bjergsø and Michael O'Brien!

_N7Ndn29bpll_961oPeEfw.review_text: Great new bar in downtown SF.  The Good:  -  I really like how the bar is organized. Lots of seating. And there a good places to stand as well. I really like the back wall with the ledge. It's a bit quieter back there so you can have a conversation.  - Service has been decent in my experience. At times it has been slow, but multiple times when a bartender sees I've been waiting to order, they would acknowledge me and say they'd be right with me, which they were.  - Pretty good food, especially for a bar, but not as good as Monk's Kettle.  - Nice modern atmosphere. I really like the brick walls and the extremely weird pantings.  - Pretty spacious, so it's good for groups.  The Bad:  - The Korean wings tasted decent, but were pretty small.  - Beers can be pretty pricey. Average ~$10 for 250ml.  - They often run out of beers. Every night I've gone (even non-busy days) they'd run out of a few beers. But at least they have a relatively large selection.  Summary: Cool bar in a good location (it's right by Little Delhi!) but it's no Monk's Kettle.

e-Bh0XDCOgYMaC-BmdxkAQ.review_text: *In spirit of Oktoberfest* If you remotely love/like beer at the same level as I do, then you must step foot into this place.  This place is incredibly serious about their brews.  May have Danish roots cuz the place has a very Euro industrial feel, metal railings, dim lighting, no windows and communal bench seating.  The menu even list the beer pours in metric.  What the hell am I getting into with a 25cl pour?!   I also know how serious they are when their Beer menu categorizes their beers according to what temperature it is going to be served.  This is unheard of in most American bars.  40 degrees for light brews such as Pilsners and American Lagers.  45 degrees for Pales, IPAs and some Belgians.  55 degrees (cellar temp)for most darks like Stouts and Porters and also Barley Wines.   And the breweries that they offer can vary across the board from a Berliner Weiss brewed in Quebec, to Cellar Maker Brewery across the street here in SF.  Don't come here already drunk or the menu will read like a chemistry text book.  Also utilize this place for flavor education as opposed to buzz development, even though the buzz is inevitable if you spend time and/or money here. I sipped off several glasses here, from fruit beers to dark stouts, all wonderfully legit.  But my stand out was a Brewfist Imperial Stout that was aged in Grappa barrels.  At $12 it was 8.7% alc served in a full wine-like glass 25cl.  It was an intense massage on the palate with deep roast, wine-y fruit and layered bitterness.  I can still taste this. Food wise, the menu is quite small but very beer compatible.  Mostly small plates and sandwiches but everything is made in house and very craft worthy.  Makes the beer sipping that much more fun. S & P Fries $6  Hand cut fries fried crisp (almost too crisp) but so good with the brews.  The malt vinegar mayo was a great twist.  Never understood dipping fries in mayo, but always loved vinegar doused fish n chips.  This worked big time!  Made me forget about the Heinz. yelp.com/biz_photos/mikk… Salt Cod Cakes $12  Nice proper texture but the filling remained quite salty.  I know it is "salt" cod, but that is the trick.  You have to pull some of the salt away to get a nice experience.  I'd skip this next time. Sausage Sampler $45  A monster aluminum cookie tray is generously laid out with 5 of their current sausages along with the paired condiment for each sausage.  This is important as each condiment rounds out the sausage experience.  For example an Apple Slaw for the Chicken-Fennel Sausage is great.  So is the classic pairing of sauerkraut with a traditional Bratwurst.  One I enjoyed was their take on a Muffaletta where they take a Mortadella Dog and pair it with an Olive Salad and Provolone.  And don't be timid on mixing different condiments with different sausages, you may find a surprise combo.  Rye toast rounds out the platter. yelp.com/biz_photos/mikk… Don't really care to hang out in this part of SF (union square area), but I most definitely would brave it for this beer joint.  I am just that serious about my brews.  Cheers!

CrNADLCTyED5OvkD0K7Eww.review_text: Excellent place for after work drinks, extensive beer list, even with a huge crowd servers always took great care of us.

g_TC2W7IqYEcAP34lgXZuA.review_text: Many beers on tap that you can ONLY find here, as the Trappist/Mikkeller partnership has remarkable synergies. You sit inside a beautifully designed interior, talking with brilliant, friendly and accessible cicerones who help you navigate the many offerings. The kitchen works hard to turn out delicious, complementary food. This place is nirvana for beer fans - and will also do a lot to help elevate a neighborhood in need of assistance...

gm87tv2u2TXFFlm-NR_Asg.review_text: The service was great even though I came on a packed Friday night. I sat down at the bar and was given the beer menu almost immediately. The menu was very extensive, and different beers are served at different temperatures. I had a Mikkeller Spontanale and a Mikkeller Mikkeller Årh Hvad?! Sauternes. The bartender poured me glasses of water without asking.   The bar is spacious and is a great place to hang out for a few beers. Beers are expensive here though, and depending on which beer you get, you may be smaller pours. I didn't order any food, but others around me did, and it smelled and looked delicious. The bar is clean and the bathroom is very clean, especially for a bar.   I'll be back if I'm craving for rare beers that I can't find at any other bar.

DJWvvie6YTka5ylcqMIXvg.review_text: Beer, oh how I love thee, let me count the ways...  I've been hearing good things about this place ever since it opened on the very edge of the Tenderloin (my least favorite part of SF) and I finally got to check it out recently on two separate occasions.  Close to BART and other public transportation so there is no need for driving and trying to find parking and after a few beers from Mikkeller, you'll need to take public transportation anyway.  Come here on a weekend and finding an open spot at the bar or at a table may be a challenge. Come here during the week on a holiday Monday and you'll have no problem finding a spot. I got to experience both and of course, I preferred the night where I could walk right up to the bar and order a beer.  The staff knows their beer so feel free to ask them any questions about the beer on the menu. Beers are categorized by the temperature they are served at and are ever changing. Mikkeller uses a "flux capacitor" gas blending system - one of only a handful in the world - allowing them precise control over each and every beer making sure it's served at the proper temperature. Fancy! Speaking of fancy, expect to pay some "fancy" prices for your beer depending on what you order and unfortunately, as far as I know, they don't have a happy hour here to save you a few bucks  Hungry? They have food here at this here gastropub. That's where the gastro of gastropub comes in. I haven't tried much off of their menu except for their bacon wrapped mini hot dogs, which were quite tasty. They do have burgers and other gastropub items which I'm sure are quite tasty, but I'm mainly here for the beer and I will most certainly be back for more.

09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w.review_text: For serious beer drinkers. The beer selection is extensive and I've enjoyed the Ellezelloise Hercule a couple times, ending a meal with their signature Red/White (red ale and Belgian white blend). Friends thought the Allagash Curieux went well with the food.  I'd go here for a small meal or something light rather than a regular sit-down dinner. Like any gastropub the place is loud so you'll be yelling dinner talk. Also, the prices are more than I'd prefer for beer and food, albeit really good beers. I'd say the costs were more representative of a dinner bill.  The place is spacious and clean. Every time I've been there it's been crowded.

O0j4EB37NeSUHVNaMlKang.review_text: I came to san francisco to visit my brother, and to take him, and my wife, to this great place i heard about from the cheese guy at whole foods.  I have been looking forward to my mikkeller visit for several months. It happened last saturday afternoon.  It was a wonderful experience.  I expected the food to be really good, but it was simply fantastic.  We ordered beemster, my favorite cheese, beehive cheese, and la tur.  I now believe la tur is in a cosmic battle to become my new favorite cheese.  And if they are offering the house bacon, you simply must order some.  I have tasted nothing like it.  The service was great.  Our server helped us with every part of our order.  I wanted a lambic, but they were only offering a sour raspberry.  I sampled some and not to my taste,  so our server suggested the clown shoes clementine.  It was perfect along with the spicy italian sausage and fries.  I will visit mikkeller every time i visit san francisco.  I look forward to trying something new every time.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: Ahhh...I didn't know this bar has its roots in Copenhagen. Wonderful, wonderful Copenhagen. Love that city. Ever since Danny Kaye played Hans Christian Andersen and sang about the ugly duckling to the little bald boy who grew up to become Moby. OK I made up the Moby part, but I do recall the beer being quite tasty in Copenhagen. And the food, too. That's what Mikkeller does right by Danish standards - balance the quality of the beer selection with that of the food menu, which is definitely better than your average bar bites or at least the bites I recall when I was sober. I came solo one evening knowing that I'd be elbow-to-elbow at the bar. It didn't turn out to be too bad as a couple of young, increasingly drunk Germans were downing shots in pints to the left of me and a young couple was to the right too enamored with each other to notice my presence. The place was fairly packed, which appears to be its normal state, and the three bartenders were kept busy. The beer selection is overwhelming (photo: bit.ly/X7yROp), so I randomly chose the $7 Table Mountain Double Burgundy Farmhouse Ale with Black Currants (photo: bit.ly/1rz7dTN). Lucky pick. It was delicious like a fruity stout. To go with it, I ordered the $14 Loukanika, a foot-long Greek sausage of pork and lamb topped with cucumber, mint and a dollop of caraway yogurt (photo: bit.ly/1nPESuw). Quite tasty with a nice oompah flavor. It came with a bag of heavily seasoned fries that seemed to encourage excessive beer drinking (photo: bit.ly/X7yHGR). It worked. In fact, I was still feeling peckish, so I ordered the $11 Millionaire's Salad, quite a yummy plate combining hearts of palm, butter lettuce, avocado, mango and hazelnuts into something really delightful (photo: bit.ly/1mXfsoz). And of course, I needed another beer to wash it all down, this time a $9 Jolly Pumpkin Oro de Calabaza, an oak-aged golden ale that hit the spot (photo: bit.ly/1qIb3xU). Meanwhile, patrons came and went as I held court on my bar stool. I'm sure I felt just like that little bald boy in Copenhagen when I came in, but I left feeling like I could sing a chorus of "Wonderful, wonderful Mikkeller!" FOOD/BEER - 4 stars...better pub fare than you would expect with the millionaire's salad a winner...food and beer are well matched AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...Danish modern but pretty crowded...be prepared to dive right in SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pretty decent once you get their attention TOTAL - 4 stars...if you are hesitant about bars like I am, you may want to check this one out on an empty stomach

3h15ylfAKK2TVGnMSSbapg.review_text: Such solid beer on tap and bartenders who describe it to you almost like wine. It's great. There are a lot of 40-tap bars scattered around the nation but how many of them have 3+ sour wild yeast beers on tap? This one.   Also one of the better reubens and wedge salads I've had in a while. This place is an excellent place to grab a quality bite and a beer.

--3l8wysfp49Z2TLnyT0vg.review_text: This place is ridiculous.  Beervana at its finest, with amazing house made sausages to boot.  Been here three times, and each has been epic.    They're always packed, so expect a little wait time for a seat, but the service is friendly and attentive, and the beer selection is tops.  There is a reason this is one of the premier beer joints in Frisco.

t1NmJ-g09NijXqycgF-evA.review_text: Very impressive beer selection, separated into sections by what temperature they're served at :o) The Reuben was very good. Not a great selection of salads. Service was nice. Decor is awesome.

shTVQJhu-NftZfRTUxYxrg.review_text: Why must all my favorite places be so far away from sunny San Mateo?  Stumbled upon this place in search of a way to kill time during rush hour, and were able to snag the last table in the joint, at around 5:30 pm - the place fills fast with all the techie guys who work in the area, which is, to be fair, a good sign.  BEER SELECTION. Impressive, not your typical SF beer menu that consists solely of every brewery within a 25 mile radius. I'm all for local brews, but it's nice to see something different! We did ask the bartender for recommendations, and I think I get a little snobby when they recommend easy, popular brews - I want to try something new and different, man! Mini-rant aside, they're well stocked here.  HALF SMOKE SAUSAGE. Stuffed with smoked beef and pork, and covered in chili, onion, and mustard - definitely the favorite of the night, not too sloppy but tons of flavor, good if you have an appetite!  MUFFULETTA. A mortadella dog topped with provolone, olives, and salame - very pretty, not too heavy, on the lighter side of the menu, but still good.  Prices aren't low, but you're in the heart of SF, you'd be hard-pressed to find a deal. Definitely worth checking out for HH or even for a quick bite if you're in the area.

7orCZxkN7st-7LWsCtHvIw.review_text: Loved it! Friendly staff, solid bratwurst, awesome beer selection, good crowd. A true hidden gem.

gflNAJSKJp4kPaxE2TCtUg.review_text: The beer selection is pretty good, Food was pretty good though the 1lb mussels were on the small side. (more shell than meat)  seating is definitely a challenge but they reserve tables for a group of 5 or more (we had a group of 4 that day.....)

idl5qpT10JlyqIqmiImiRQ.review_text: Starting with the location: Is not the best place to hang out after 8 pm if you dont have a car. Despite that, the place its very fancy and has a really cool decoration. But you know what? When i choose a beer bar, it should be about the beer, therefore, the 8 buck beer served in a tiny glass is a bit snooby. Great variety of draft beer, but OVERPRICED - Sorry, i wont buy it.

Vwny4WEUEnWUXmOZNkuRdQ.review_text: Heck yah, was glad I was able to hit this place on my vacation to San Francisco. I had quite a few breweries and brew pubs on my list and this was not one of them. Luckily it was right down the street from my hotel and I came across it.   I was super excited to see the vast list of beers on tap that ranged from some hop heavy IPA to infused and aged stouts. My wife and I split the Reuben Sandwich. It was a great sandwich and for the price filled the both of us up. Great bread and some damn good mustard.   Place gets packed on Friday and Saturdays but our server really kicked some ass. Chatted with us about beer and let us try a few samples. Place was pretty loud but if you can post up behind the bar you can enjoy some conversation. CHEERS!!

4RlzFohEgBdFXUGoqvpZqQ.review_text: Honesty, I should probably give this place 5 stars because I really can't think of anything bad to say. I've been here a handful of times now. It gets packed for HH, but I've still been able to score a seat. If you're meeting people near Powell Bart it's a quick walk into the TL. Tons of beers on tap, food, big open space, what's not to like?  They are also open Sunday's until midnight!

fcxVNd3NmFLrDb5Xx10ipg.review_text: Super crowded but a great beer selection and the bartenders are very helpful. Mikkeler makes some very interesting brews.

qt-_SN5eEmvf0rOrlp_MGQ.review_text: I'm a semi-regular at The Trappist and have never tried a Mikkeller beer...until now. I'm a fan of the beer and this fine establishment. This place is a beer lovers Mecca.

p6qMidPaJ96LgB_9z7xZVw.review_text: I really love how everything is laid out at this bar. The atmosphere is relaxed, the taps look amazing, and the selection is varied enough that just about anyone can find something they'll love to drink here.  They also provide some small bites (and larger ones if you're hungry), and I've had their S&P Fries. Super crispy, just how I like 'em. My next goal is to inhale their Lil' Smokies.  The main room is pretty large, but make sure you get here pretty early because the seats fill up quick at the bar and at the assorted tables. There's also a "sour room" that I don't believe is open yet down the stairs, where they will eventually feature a bunch of sours that will be sure to tickle your palate if you're into that kind of thing (I'm not, but Boyfriend is waiting with bated breath for it).  Overall, the bartenders are really nice and the vibe is pretty relaxed. There's a nice mix of business people grabbing a drink after work and tourists because of its location off Powell, but everyone for the most part just seems to be enjoying a brew. But just keep in mind that, because it's so near to a "touristy" area, the prices may be a bit higher than you expect a beer place to have.

cSNER_qF_bb1t7kN0kZ44Q.review_text: Great addition to the bar scene in San Francisco - it's a great place to come with coworkers, friends or on a casual date. The ambiance is great - with high ceilings and enough space, it doesn't feel cramped, too dark, or too loud. They have a wide selection of beers on tap with interesting and unique flavors, at reasonable prices. The food tends to be priced on the above average side, especially for the quantity of food that you're getting. Typical gastropub prices; it's not terribly overpriced but the drinks are certainly a better value for your dollar than the food is.  I got a saison beer and the AleSmith Nut Brown Ale (English Brown Ale) and they were both really delicious.  For food, my friend and I decided to order two of the sausages and split them. They are a great combo with the beer, and fries or salad are included. At $14 a pop, they are certainly not cheap; in comparison, Rosamunde's are usually $6-7, but without topping and without the side.  Texas Ranger ($14) - All-beef, fried onion & jalapeño and chipotle ranch. If you like spicy foods, you'll like this one.  The fried onion & jalapeño definitely give it a nice crunch and a kick. The sausage was good, but a little on the dry side and it could have been much bigger. (Not sure how to word all of this part of my review so it doesn't sound dirty, but get your mind out of the gutter ;)) It was just barely wider than a Slim Jim.  Half Smoke ($14) - Smoked Beef & Pork, Chili, Onion, Mustard. This was juicy and had a good smokey flavor. I liked the addition of the chili. It was not over-complicated with too many toppings, and you could really just enjoy the taste of the meat.  I'd definitely recommend coming here if you're in the area - it's a bit tucked away on Mason but really close to Union Square and the Powell St. BART. I think it's one of the better food / drink establishments in the area as far as bars are concerned, and really easy to get to via public transit. I'll be back for more delicious beer and food!

c2IcHHOTgQXf-9AA0DLLRw.review_text: Tons of beers you probably won't find at a lot of places, but not to the extent of a place like Monk's Kettle (which is a bit more pricey too).  I didn't get the food, so I didn't experience the 'gastro' part; however, the drinks were fairly priced so that's a plus.    The place was really packed, and I don't think I would have waited for the experience, but because I was sitting as soon as I walked in and the waitress was cool, no issues.  Yeah the neighborhood sucks, but this whole part of the city is full of scum or tourists anyway...the bar itself is full of tech dorks.

rNAMfSZWTjHhaoxat468_w.review_text: The beer selection is so different and phenomenal.  Only 1 IPA on tap of 40, which will challenge the typical west coast hop head.  The bartender had a lot of knowledge without the snobbery.    The Rueben was amazing.  The meat was perfectly cooked.  There wasn't too much bread and it had a great rye flavor.  The side salad was simple and tasted like it was uprooted minutes before I ate it.    There were some service kinks, but for a new place, it was not bad at all.    I can't wait to have the opportunity to go there again.

1rB0IJVN7kz9AXCP1SSPrA.review_text: Man i've been wanting to hit this place since I heard it had opened last year. Huge fans of Mikkeller - their beer, artwork and style are second to none in my humble opinion. We finally found ourselves in SF for mine and my wife's 12 year anniversary - super hyped!  Located just off Market on Mason Street (outskirts of the Tenderloin), you would almost walk right past it if it weren't for the lit up Mikkeller sign on the side of the building. Very unassuming from the outside, but once you step inside you are greeted by a rustic yet refined look and feel to the joint. The back wall left alone in all brick, the clean and simple European minimalist design, and walls adorned with Keith Shore artwork let you know that you are definitely at a Mikkeller bar.   Their draft system is clean, efficient and gorgeous stainless steel placed perfectly within a quad bartop that is powered by the Flux Capacitor draft system that keeps each beer style at its proper serving temperature - meaning your BA Imperial Stouts aren't served as cold as your IPA's, your Wild Ales served at proper temps to bring out the ultimate amount of funk and unique characteristics, and to assure that your Pilsner is served cold and crisp to pair perfectly with a sausage sandwich and crispy double fried french fries. Genius!  Quite an eclectic crowd - my wife and I heavily tattoo'd and casually dressed seated right next to business men in suits and ties and women dressed up for a night on the town in nice dresses and heals - it all works out quite well somehow. There is open bar seating and reserved seating as well, which can be a bit tricky - where there was open seating (first come first serve) our first night in, the next night it was reserve seating. I think this is a little confusing for the guests, but we were able to get seated within our first drink both nights.   We were fortunate enough to get a full tour of the inner-workings of the bar by Cellar Master Ford, who showed us the renowned Flux Capacitor system, where they cellar the kegs on deck, their cask system, and answered any questions we had with enthusiasm and a smile on his face. I tried my best not to geek out too hard! We also had tremendous service from our beer server Natalia, who not only had knowledge of all the beers being served, but knew about the cheeses we paired with our beers as well (names, origins, and types of cheeses) - as most know, you often get a blank stare when asking your server what cheese are in front of you when they are brought to the table.  Mikkel was in town for a dinner/beer pairing in the Tivoli Sour Room (reserved for special events - located downstairs) so to honor his visit, the bar had 42 taps of all Mikkeller beer on tap. It was beyond amazing. Beers I never thought I would try on tap were literally at my fingertips. 7 Spontan varieties, 5 Beer Geek varieties, Black Tokyo Horizon, just to name a few. I was blown away!  Overall we had extremely high hopes and left the bar far from disappointed. In fact we had a better experience than we could have imagined. Special thanks to Cellar Master Ford, and one of the finest beer servers in the business (and i've been in this industry for nearly 20 years) Natalia. The two of you along with the rest of the staff are top notch and have a true passion for good beer and proper hospitality. We can't wait to visit again.  Cheers!

GMOzZgT-WB9KqJ_B_8xiyA.review_text: Great selection of beers and definitely worth a visit. I ate an eggplant parm and fries which was okay, but I'd probably go for something else in the future.

WhhOoUlXC9Xbw93vYzgCzQ.review_text: I've been here twice (no, make it thrice) since it has opened, and I will go out on a limb and say this is the best beer bar in SF.  Sorry, Toronado.  Monk's Kettle, not sorry for you.  The beer selection is phenomenal.  Lots of Mikkeller of course; easy to get a bottle of Cantillon as well.  I still haven't tried the food but I know I will be there again.  I have to say I love the logo on the merchandise as well.

tJNADammQ_Ia6xqKAbQgtw.review_text: Cool vibe and ambiance exposed brick and high ceiling. Mikkeller Bar was fairly busy after the work day. The bar was full, and if you prefer to sit at the communal tables or booths, you need to speak with one of the hosts.  Overall I thought it was a bit overpriced and quality of food was okay. Beer and wine only, with an extensive beer selection, and limited wine choices. Service was slow but friendly. I think they were short staffed and busy. I ordered the bratwurst, which was a generous portion, but unfortunately contained pieces of cartilage. My friend said her chicken breast dish was bland, but worked since she was having her stomach issues. We shared the cherry & chocolate bread pudding which tasted decent but lacked in both the major ingredients in most of my bites.  My bill was over $50 with tax and tip, which seems a bit much for a mediocre food and dining experience. It would be nice if they included happy hour. This place is good for a beer and to share apps with friends, but I don't recommend it for a full sit down meal.

JBKxKQ_FCeIj-b3wtUk0Zw.review_text: Decent beer selection but horribly overpriced food. $12 for a footlong hotdog 'half smoke'? Nothing like DC half smokes. The food quality is underwhelming and loaded with salt. It seems that most of the pricing structure goes into paying the rent.

VdOTg5a-NbQyXcrvKjwxLw.review_text: If it wasn't for my friend who raved about this place, I probably wouldn't have had the chance to check this place out.  One thing for sure though...if you love beer and sausages, this place is for you.  If you love bacon wrapped anything, this is also the place for you.    Great way to start Friday after work with a casual happy hour.  Arrived somewhere close to 5:30pm and the bar and all the tables were already taken, so we settled for seating by the window.  Let me know tell you...there were so many different beers to choose from I could have just stayed here all night.    Eventually, ended up trying the Allegash White (Allegash Brewing Co.) and Pivo Hippy Pills (Firestone Walker).  There was just something about the name that made me curious enough to order it...Also had the Lil Smokies, or better known as bacon wrapped hot dogs.  In this case though, it was a little too literal, as a few of the hot dogs were a little burnt, but not so you couldn't eat them at all.  Bratwurst and fries was also quickly devoured, but the sauerkraut dominated my taste buds.    Service was good all around even though we were seated on the opposite end of the bar, and I swear I don't remember the waitress giving me my credit card back when we got the bill, and to my shock and awe, it was already in my wallet.  Wah wah!?  Magic!  Okay, probably not...but I did feel slightly silly...

pudxkSYxLCQw7dhupri24g.review_text: Great beer selection and a fun food menu too. Chill vibe on a weekend afternoon.  I don't know much about beer but the bartender was super helpful on making recommendations, giving me tastings so I can choose and just being all around sweet.  We ordered the bacon wrapped lil smokies (because we're fatties), and they were delicious.  I wanted to try the sausages, but we were just too full. Next time...  The only downside is you're right near the corner of turk and mason, so the surrounding area can be less than savory. But just....hustle in, and sit down, you'll be fine.

R3745ij-KXIREK7sKuCTWg.review_text: Went here based on a recommendation from a local friend.  I was walking down Market Street anyway so this was just a half block off my route.  I was surprised to find such a nice brew pub in the Tenderloin (well, on the outskirts of the 'loin).  Really nice brewery ambiance inside with lots of tables, bar space, and a huge tap selection of beers.  My waiter was super friendly/helpful and offered up suggestions and a taste of the IPA I ended up drinking.  I only had beer, no food.  I'd definitely go back to eat and drink here.

goJ0EFodzx76FeWDQcIzuA.review_text: I've been excited for Mikkeller to open in San Francisco, but I fear for its future. This city has plenty of places to drink with snobby hipsters, but I thought the selection at Mikkeller would oultast the crowd. Too bad the service lacks in comparison to the menu's prices.  Alas, the management (Bob) was as snobby as the clientele. The service a month after opening was friendly but uncoordinated - which reflects on poor leadership more than on the workers themselves.  I had high hopes, but I'll continue to look elsewhere for overpriced imported beers.

w6gKfNnGMVvSfF3VmNYTBA.review_text: For such a busy place, the bartenders and wait staff are extremely friendly and knowledgeable.

fERvVR78dqj6SixSFSj7Ng.review_text: Prepare for this place to blow up. I already saw it on Refinery 29 as a top pick to check out in the TL (although there aren't a lot, it's getting there). It's basically like a beer bar that acts like a wine bar but is definitely a beer bar...The beer is priced on the higher end side and the beer menu changes quickly.   I work right around the block so this is my after work "need a drink" spot. I've had quite a bit of the menu over my past three times here so here's a rundown on what I've grubbed on: The chicken options were quite tasty! I saw another reviewer say it needed to be cooked more, and I agree...a little red near the bone. Beware, the FRIES ARE ADDICTING! The Fish cakes were good but a tad bland...needs a little something. Vietnamese pork sandwich was HUGE. Split it with someone because it get's filling really quick.    Service--First two times were perfect and on point. The third time it took forever for us to be noticed and we had to flag down a waiter. I hate being that patron but it had to be done! They forgot our chicken wings but luckily we got full enough on the dishes we already ordered.  The area is sketchy but close enough to Powell & Market where it's not in the deep of the TL madness.

TiPH2ZwSX53uK7IvFSHVYg.review_text: Casual meet up between friends over beer? Great spot! If you are looking for food or hard liquor they are a bit weak on the former (compared to places in the mission) and lack the latter. I think it is a great after dinner spot or if you just want a few bites while you drink.  We drove and it took a bit to find good parking (where my windows would be still intact if I parked on the street). The inside is very nice/clean, the service is great, and they have a lot of draft beers. I would just tell the bartender what I was looking for and all the recs were great.

CiQk5MWr2uF5KtkUUgMj9A.review_text: Came here after dinner so only snacked on the bacon wrapped little smokies late, can't say anything about the rest of the food menu.  But the beer list is great. Expansive, with different styles served in their proper vessel and listed in groups by their serving temperature. Had a group with various tastes in beer, from hop heads to sour fans and there was a little something for everyone.  I opted for some off-the-wall choices, like an oak barrel aged IPA and an imperial chocolate stout with ancho chile. Tried a saison (when in Rome...) but still do not like that style.  The area is a little sketchy (watch out for puddles of urine outside) but worth the drive over from downtown.

oBzcnbpWF4dNLP8r0F99qQ.review_text: Obviously places in the Tenderloin aren't in the best of neighborhoods (while i was walking up to the bar at 5 in the afternoon, I saw a guy break into a car and steal a suitcase in front of 100 or so other people) That's the reason for the 4 and not 5 star review...   Once you're inside, the environment is nice, the staff is knowledgeable, the beer is delicious. I do have to go back and try the food. Next time I go, I think i'll just start at the top and work my way down the list :)

RCKdmKDZRd-RovZVtNSCLA.review_text: Amicable, knowledgeable bartenders spice up this place at least much as their huge selection on tap. Aside from Ron and the Evil Twin Ryan (mmm!), there are a good amount of sour drinks -- this is a good thing; I inquired!  During one occasion, my other half was experiencing their last day of vegan season, so they ordered several sodas. Another friend and I poked fun here, considering that all sodas technically have yeast... I shall say no more, but have fun with where I was headed, folks!

6Jd9HoopF-OoeVdjfd4mTg.review_text: Transcendent.  Divine.  Splendiferous. These words are are typically reserved for spiritual experiences in life.  However in the hour and a half or so I spent at Mikkellar Bar I felt all of the above.  It's hard to imagine as much based on the neighborhood (Tenderloin) close by but this is a waterhole close to nothing.  If there is such a thing as capturing lightning in a bottle well these guys managed to pull a Mr. Wizard by capturing it in a tulip glass.  Seriously they know what they're doing.  This is not your daddy's waterhole.  Only mature palettes would appreciate this establishment.  Richard, the elixir attendant that kindly assisted us through our barreled aged voyage redefined the term bartender.  I make such a proclamation because he did not merely serve me a beverage he bestowed an experience upon us.  Never will I look at the consumption of fermented beverages the same way.  What I'm basically trying to say is, if you care half a shit about what you drink, and you're in San Francisco, please go visit the Mikkeller Bar, you will not be disappointed.  And be sure to ask for Richard, he will guide you through the magnificent world of "liquid bread".

bsMGQruRQGgQZK4KA9Q4Aw.review_text: I was told the salt cod cakes were listed as one of "100 Things to Eat in San Francisco Before You Die" and I was in!   As a SF virgin, I knew very little about Mikkeller or the restaurant scene in general, but this sounded right up my alley. Even on a Monday night, it was hoppin'. We sat at a hightop and with others sitting on either side of us and it was almost impossible to have an audible conversation. No worries though, we were both too busy stuffing our faces the majority of the time anyways.   The salt cod cakes demonstrated why they deserved a spot on that aforementioned list. While they brought back very fond memories of eating fishsticks as a kid, they were certainly more sophisticated. I could've had multiple orders but then there was mac n cheese... While it's true it's hard to mess up mac n cheese, this was especially good. On top of that, we had the S&P fries (as you can see, we were pretty concerned with our waistlines this particular evening). With these three dishes, we were full and satisfied.   Of course, the beer here was great. I had never seen a beer menu divided by temperature and went with what I was comfortable with, the Mikkeller Tenderloin Wit. On my next visit, I'd probably go a little slower on the food as to prolong my time here and try multiple kinds since it seems the beer is really what's up!

VvMDnYfkfwyLXfl_ei37Vg.review_text: Too loud lights way too dim. great almonds. good beer selection

zjngZLOqfgdVJI6nudhtbg.review_text: The lil smokies were good and a large portion.  We also had the reuben was decent.  My biggest complaint was that they seemed to be out of a lot of items and were uninterested in suggesting alternatives

Kkl36D9gv7kahlcVifqYQg.review_text: A bald bartender made a comment about my weight and told me "if you get any fatter you'd break the plate glass window" and pretended to shoot himself as he walked away.

R7lf-XSUvjITu8gLa1uscw.review_text: Was looking for a mid-week happy hour place near work and stumbled upon Mikkeller Bar.  The outside and location do not do justice to this place.  Stunning indoor set up that makes you feel like this is truly a beer palace!  Enjoyed some great beers and snacks a couple days in a row.  Staff and patrons all seemed to be having a good time.  Will definitely keep coming back here.

MdUimpfJQHijcy1DZu-r4A.review_text: A co-worker brought me to Mikkeller a few weeks ago and I was impressed. The tap selection was excellent. A good mix of Belgians and American IPA's. The food was very good too. The sausages were very impressive and the appetizer options were creative and well executed. The service was pretty good considering the place was packed too.

8J5gkxtQPyZcG_JFzqgQUw.review_text: This place is off the hoooook. Hella beer choices- all unique and bold with flavor. I can't remember what I got...it had pumpkin in the name of it, and it was amazing. My friend got this beer with like 17% alcohol content and it was craziness on the tongue.  Food was perfection too. I got a reuben and my friend got the eggplant sandwich. Both were bursting with flavor and the french fries were perfectly fried.    It's a tad pricey- expect to spend $30 for a meal + 2 beers, but it's worth it.  The atmosphere is perfection too. It's dim and artsy, a bit hipster. It does get very crowded and loud, so expect to hover around the bar to snatch a seat.
